snippet: Some brokers of JPMorgan Chase say that the bank’s profits were put ahead of the needs of investors in order to make up for lost boom-era revenues.
abstract: Editorial observes that some JPMorgan Chase bankers say that the bank's profits were put ahead of the needs of investors, and that they felt pressure to sell mutual funds the bank created, even when there were better options available to customers; laments that attempts by the Security and Exchange Commission to impose a fiduciary duty on brokers who give investment advice have been stymied by financial-industry opposition and weak Congressional support.
lead_paragraph: Some brokers of JPMorgan Chase say that the bank’s profits were put ahead of the needs of investors in order to make up for lost boom-era revenues.

headline.seo: Want to Buy a Mutual Fund?
headline.main: Want to Buy a Mutual Fund?
headline.print_headline: Want to Buy a Mutual Fund?
